repnme.cdata!: Gambia - Public Works and Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The implementing agency (AGETIP) demonstrated
            that it could deliver cost-effective civil works through
            efficient and transparent delegated contract management
            procedures, while generating substantial employment and
            receiving no external technical assistance. Key lessons
            learned are summed up as follows: The sustainability of
            sub-projects and the survival of many of the small and
            medium-size construction firms (SMEs) created during project
            implementation hinges on the delivery of quality works and
            services. New training workshops in standard design and
            supervision procedures for consultants need to be run.
            Strengthening training packages in general management, site
            management, and tender preparation will be important for
            contractors. Improving the systematic collection of labor
            and income-related data on SMEs in the local private sector
            constitutes an important next step toward assessing the
            poverty alleviation effects of employment-generating
            interventions in the public works area. Strengthening
            municipal capacities is a key to ensuring sub-project
            sustainability; sub-projects will struggle as long as local
            governments falter in developing technical and managerial
            capacity for long-term investment programming and in
            improved tax collection. The Bank should clearly state that
            the agency's operating costs will be financed in the
            future on a declining basis, as the agency moves toward a
            fee-for-service system.

18157390.owner: AFT:  Urban/Water Francophone (AFTU2),Env., NRM, WRM & DRM Prac 2 (AFTN2),8841

repnme.cdata!: Gambia - Public Works and Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Works and Capacity Building
            Project's objectives are to: (a) build local capacity;
            (b) assist the government in maintaining infrastructure
            assets; and (c) participate in reducing the current
            unemployment issue by creating temporary jobs in the public
            works and the construction sector. The project has three
            main components. The first component is an investment
            component aimed at protecting the existing infrastructure
            from decay and developing additional urgently needed social
            infrastructure. The program of labor intensive subprojects
            includes two types of operations: (a) public works including
            routine maintenance of roads, rehabilitation of drainage
            system; and urban infrastructure; and (b) public services,
            notably cleaning up spoiled urban areas as well as testing
            private management practices of waste collection. The second
            component is capacity building through training and
            technical support for the beneficiaries and small- and
            medium-sized enterprises aimed at: (a) enhancing the
            technical capacity of domestic construction contractors and
            local consultants; (b) improving the management of public
            infrastructure by local governments, and emphasizing
            maintenance of new construction; and (c) improving public
            procurements and contract management practices. The third
            component is a study component aimed at defining more
            broadly-based improvements in the urban infrastructure
            maintenance management; and the private sector participation
            as a support of the project in general and the preparation
            of the urban environment project.
